text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- Philips Electronics starts 1997 "reasonably well" with Dfl 887 million net profit in Q1 from Dfl 692 in Q1 of 1996. (p1)
- Government reaches agreement with local and provincial authority organisations about the way the treasury funds local services. (p1)
- S.E. Beelaerts van Blokland leaves merchant bank MeesPierson's board due to differences of opinion. (p1)
- Accountancy organisation VB Groep is looking for a partner for cooperation or merger. (p1)
- Consumer confidence in the Netherlands remains at a high level in April. (p1)
- Publisher De Telegraaf will not succeed in matching 1995 record earnings this year. (p3)
- Suspension maker Weweler is forecasting improved turnover and profits. (p5)
- The average price of an owner-occupied home rose ten percent in the first three months of this year. (p7)
VOLKSKRANT
- Number of mixed farms is rapidly increasing in the Netherlands. (p1)
- Employers association VNO-NCW chairman calls for self- regulation of companies' share options schemes. (p2)
- Royal Dutch/Shell employees in the Netherlands allowed to work 37 hours a week on a voluntary base next year. (p7)
- High pork prices, not swine fever, are largest danger for the sector. (p7)
DE TELEGRAAF
- Ajax Amsterdam loses 4-1 to Italy's Juventus in return leg of the semi-final of the Champions' League. (p1)
- Cabinet is to enforce total ban on pyramid schemes. (p1)
- IMF warns of inflation due to rapidly growing Dutch economy. (p35)
- Automation group Baan Company more than doubles Q1 net from Dfl 8.3 million to Dfl 23.7 million. (p37)
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- Strike action at SHB in the port of Rotterdam postponed. (p10)
- Brewer Bavaria books small profit growth in 1996 from Dfl 30.6 million to Dfl 31.03 million. (p10)
- ABN AMRO bank, ING and Rabobank plan to refuse racist clients. (p11)
TROUW
- Finance minister Gerrit Zalm fears businesses will exaggerate costs of Euro conversion. (p6)
